fol.153v
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight Principall secretary to her Ma
tie
31 Dec:
1588
M
r
Thomas Bodleighe
Co
u
t Meurs
his letters s
e
t to his
wyfe
, himself beinge absent.
Dev
e
ter
,
Clarhagh
,
Aysma
,
Leyden
m
e
&
Skenk
, written unto, to know what he shall doe in their causes.
Skenk hath yelded up his castel to
e
D. of Cleve
.
Gilpin
to be interp
r
ter is thoght wilbe misliked.
desireth Advertisem
e
ts.
page.lettertext:
31 De
c
88
fol.152r
It may please yo
r
H. I receaved yesternight yo
r
H. of
e 19 and an other of
e 21 of this p
nt
, w
t
a
letter from her
Ma
tie
to
e Count de Meurs: who is
gone towardes
Arnham
, w
t
a 1000 footmen, and 600
horse. But I sent
e letter this morning to
Utrecht
to the Countesse his wife, and the copie therof w
t
all,
w
t
a letter unto her from my self, framing my style,
as by c
o
ference heere, and by notice taken of her dispo-
sition, I found very requisit. Likewise I have written
to
e Count, and to
e
chief Magistrat
and Burgmasters
of
e towne, who, as I understand, beare
e greatest
sway in these proceedinges. I have putte
e Count in
minde of those wordes in his letter,
qu'en cas qu'
ils soient trouvez inculpables,
q
' selon le bon desir
de v
re
Ma
te
seront remis en pleine libert
: w
ch
I have signified unto him her Hig
nes
can not repute
for any courtesie, considering if they should be found
inculpable, extremitie of justice would affourd their
deliverance. I have also written to Deventer him-
self, and to Clarhaghe, to those of Leiden, Aisma and
Schincke, to knowe what course I may best take, to
effectuat their desires. Of Schincke it hath bin heere
reported, albeit most men hold it untrue, that for
40000 dallers to himself, and 3 monethes pay to his
souldiers, he hath yelded up his fort to
e D. of Cleve
who hath accepted him as Mareschall. In her
Ma
ties
letter unto
e states, M
r
Gilpin is c
o
mended,
unto them, as one
at should assist me in
e place of
an Interpreto
r
, w
ch
is feared by
M
r
Killegrew
,
will occasion some scruple among them: for that it
wilbe construed for a kinde of innovation, wherto
they wilbe hardly drawen, because, as he saith,
ei
doe not greatly affect him. And by reason heerof
in c
o
ference together, they thought it expedient, that
I would stay my presentac
o
n to
e
Councell
, untill this
day. Being incombred uppon this my first arri-
vall w
t
heapes of informations, and busines, I am
forced to omitte many maters in answear to my pub-
lick and privat instructions, untill a fitter opportunitie:
fol.152v
wherof I am to request yo
r
H. best acceptance, as
also of my humble thankes for yo
r
comfortable newes
out of
Fraunce
. Contrary to expectation I
doe finde by report that this towne is very barren
of forraine intelligence and yet
e chiefest persons
very inquisitive: that if yo
r
H. will vouchesafe
to cause some one of yo
r
s, as occurrence of consequence
shall happen, to write it unto me, I hope to make it
serve for
e advauncement of my service, in that
by imparting it heere, they will be more willing to
communicat their advertisments and state of all
thinges w
t
me. Heere is newes from
Andwerp
of
e
K. of Poland
his death by poison, and of
the
D. of Parma
his provision to marche towardes
Pa-
ris
for succo
r
of
e Liguers, wherew
t
and w
t
other
like newes I will not troble yo
r
H. till I see
more likelihood, or understand greater certaintie.
And so I take my humble leave. From
e Haghe
. De
c
. 31. 88.
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
